case_name: B. V. Subhaiah Ors v. State of Andhra Pradesh Ors

facts.text: Batch of writ petitions Nos. 144, 216, 217, 221, 223, 242, 247 to 249, 308 and 324 of 1970 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 144, 216, 217, 221, 223, 242, 247 to 249, 308 and 324 of 1970. Petition under Article 32 of the Constiution of India for the enforecement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Writ petitions raise common questions of fact and law and heard together.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Dua, This batch of writ petitions raise companymon questions of fact and law and have, therefore, been heard together and ,are being disposed of by a companymon judgment.

facts.text: Facts illustrated by Writ Petition No. 217 of 1970 by B. V. Subhaiah Ors v. State of Andhra Pradesh Ors filed by 387 teachers.

anchor.surface_text: As the salient features of all the writ petitions are similar in essential particulars, we may, for understanding the nature of the companytroversy, only refer to the facts of writ Petition No. 217 of 1970  B. V. Subhaiah Ors v. State of Andhra Pradesh Ors.

facts.text: Petitioners pray for writ of mandamus restraining respondents from giving effect to G.O. Ms. No. 2219 dated November 3, 1967, Memo No. 6573 dated November 8, 1968, G.O. Ms. No. 1321 dated June 17, 1969, substituted r.14 under Municipalities Act and r.16 under Panchayat Samitis Act.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No. 217 of 1970 has been presented in this Court by 387 teachers under Art. 32 of the Constitution praying for a writ in the nature of mandamus or order or direction restraining the respondents from giving effect to, the orders, G. O. Ms. No. 2219 dated November 3, 1967, read with Government of Andhra Pradesh Memo No. 6573 dated November 8, 1968 and G. O. Ms. No. 1321 dated June 17, 1969, the substituted r. 14 of the Rules made under the Andhra Pradesh Municipalities Act, and  iii  the substituted r. 16 of the Rules made under the Panchayat Samitis and Zilla Parishads Act.

facts.text: Petitioners are permanent teachers working in service of Zilla Parishads, Panchayat Samitis and Municipalities for last 25 or 30 years.

anchor.surface_text: These petitioners claim to be working as permanent teachers in the service of Zilla Parishads, Panchayat Samitis and Municipalities for the last 25 or 30 years.

facts.text: Retirement age for teachers in Andhra Pradesh Government, Zilla Parishads, Panchayat Samitis and Municipalities fixed at 55 years.

anchor.surface_text: According to their averments, the retirement age for the teachers in the service of the Andhra Pradesh Government, Zilla Parishads, Panchayat Samitis and the Municipalities is fixed at 55 years.

facts.text: Under F.R. 56(a) and Subsidiary Rules, government servant may be retained after 55 years with Government sanction, up to 60 in special circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Under F. R. 56 a  and the Subsidiary Rules of the Andhra Pradesh Government 1962, a government servant may however be retained in service after companypleting 55 years with the sanction of the Government and in special circumstances he may even be retained in service after 60 years.

facts.text: Rule 14 under Andhra Pradesh Municipalities Act 1959 and r.16 under Zilla Parishads and Panchayat Samitis Act 1959 fix retirement at 55 years.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 14 of the Establishment Rules made under the Andhra Pradesh Municipalities Act, 1959, and r. 16 of the Rules made under the Andhra Pradesh Zilla Parishads and Panchayat Samitis Act, 1959, also fix the age of retirement at 55 years for the employees of these bodies.

facts.text: G.O. Ms. No. 3099 dated November 20, 1964 raised age of superannuation to 58 years for Head-Masters and teaching staff in Government, Zilla Parishads, Panchayat Samitis and Municipalities subject to medical fitness etc.

anchor.surface_text: On November 20, 1964, the Government of Andhra Pradesh issued G. O. Ms. No. 3099 raising the age of superannuation to 58 years subject to medical fitness-and satisfactory work and companyduct in respect of the Head-Masters and teaching staff in Government service and also in the institutions under the Zilla Parishads and Panchayat Samitis and Municipalities.

facts.text: G.O. Ms. No. 1596 dated June 28, 1966 raised age of retirement to 60 years subject to conditions.

anchor.surface_text: On June 28, 1966, the Education Department of Andhra Pradesh issued G. O. Ms. No. 1596 raising the age of retirement to 60 years subject to certain companyditions.

facts.text: Clarification issued on August 26, 1966 that extension up to 60 years subject to medical fitness and satisfactory work and conduct.

anchor.surface_text: On August 26, 1966, a clarification was issued whereby extension of service upto 60 years was stated to be subject to only two companyditions, namely, medical fitness and satis- factory work and companyduct.

facts.text: G.O. Ms. No. 2219 dated November 3, 1967 cancelled earlier orders extending retirement age from 55 to 58 and 58 to 60 effective from November 30, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: On November 3, 1967 the Government of Andhra Pradesh issued G. O. Ms. No. 2219 cancelling with effect from November 30, 1967, the earlier Government orders extending the age of retirement of teachers, first from 55 to 58 and then from 58 to 60 years.

facts.text: G.O. 2219 directed making suitable rules under Panchayat Samitis and Municipalities Acts.

anchor.surface_text: This order also companytained a direction for making suitable rules under the Panchayat Samitis and Municipalities Act separately, by the Panchayat Raj and Health, Housing and Municipal Administration Departments so as to give effect to the Governments decision.

facts.text: Teachers affected by G.O. 2219 continued in service till end of academic year 1967-68.

anchor.surface_text: It was however provided in this order that the teachers affected thereby would be companytinued in service till the end of the academic year 1967-68 in order to ensure companytinuity in the academic teaching.

facts.text: New r.16 substituted on November 16, 1967 reducing age to 55 for Panchayat Samitis and Zilla Parishads.

anchor.surface_text: On November 16, 1967, new r. 16 was substituted for old r. 16 by means of which the age of superannuation of officers and servants of Panchayat Samits and Zilla Parishads was reduced to 55 years.

facts.text: New r.14 substituted on November 20, 1967 reducing retirement age to 55 for Municipalities employees.

anchor.surface_text: On November 20, 1967, new r. 14 was substituted for the old r. 14, similarly reducing the retirement age to 55 years, in respect of the employees of the establishments under the Municipalities.

facts.text: Fundamental Rules 56(a) amended on March 14, 1968 by adding Note 2 allowing retirement after compulsory age without notice.

anchor.surface_text: On March 14, 1968, Fundamental Rules 56 a  was amended by the Governor under Art. 309 of the Constitution by adding to it Note 2, according to which a government servant retained in service after the date of companypulsory retirement companyld be retired at any time without numberice and without assigning any reason.

facts.text: Some teachers approached Andhra Pradesh High Court under Art. 226; Chinnappa Reddy J. allowed writs on April 16, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that some teachers, other than the present petitioners, feeling aggrieved by these orders approached the Andhra Pradesh High Court for relief under Art. 226 of the Constitution. On April 16, 1968, Chinnappa Reddy, J., allowed those writ petitions and directed the Andhra Pradesh Government number to give ,effect to G. O. Ms. No. 2219 dated November 3, 1967, and the amendment to the Fundamental Rule and the Rules under the Municipalities Act, Panchayat Samitis and Zilla Parishads Act, insofar as they affected the rights of the petitioners in those petitions.

facts.text: Another batch of teachers' writs disposed by same judge on August 7, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Those writ petitions were disposed of by the same learned Judge on August 7, 1968.

facts.text: Division Bench of AP High Court on April 14, 1969 upheld single judge holding cancellation inoperative.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal from the earlier judgment of the learned Single Judge, a Division Bench of the Andhra Pradesh High Court on April 14, 1969, agreed with the single bench in holding that the ,cancellation of the extension of the service of the writ petitioners by the impugned orders was inoperative.

facts.text: Government Memo dated November 8, 1968 issued providing retention for teachers with specific extensions up to 58 or 60.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, in pursuance of the judgment of the learned Single Judge the Government had on November 8, 1968, issued a Government Memo providing as under Teachers employed by Municipalities, Zilla Parishad and Panchayat Samithis. Teachers whose services have been extended up to the age of 60 years by specific individual orders should be retained in service until they attain that age.

facts.text: Government Memorandum No. 5929/HI/68 dated March 17, 1969 directed not to oust teachers who attained 55 before Nov 30, 1967 without extension orders.

anchor.surface_text: On March 17, 1969, the Government issued a Memorandum  No. 5929/HI/68  directing all the Block Development Officers,. Secretaries of Zilla Parishads and Secretaries of Municipal Councils number to oust the teachers who had attained 55 years of age before November 30, 1967, merely because there were numberextension orders in their favour.

facts.text: G.O. Ms. No. 1321 dated June 17, 1969 amended r.16 under Panchayat Samitis and Zilla Parishads.

anchor.surface_text: On June 17, 1969, r. 16 2  of the Rules relating to the establishments under the Panchayat Samitis and Zilla Parishads was amended. so as to bring it in companyformity with the decision arrived at pursuant to the judgment of the High Court.

facts.text: Petitioners aggrieved by clause (d) of Government Memo dated November 8, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners before us are feeling aggrieved by cl.  d  of the Memorandum issued by the Government on November 8, 1968, and it is this clause which is the main target of challenge. on behalf of the petitioners.

facts.text: All writ petitions dismissed with no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the final result, all the writ petitions are dismissed, but in the circumstances with numberorder as to companyts.

holdings.text: The impugned Government order fixing November 30, 1967, as the date for founding the classification of teachers who should retire at the age of 55 years and those who should get the benefit of the interim orders extending the age of retirement to 58 or 60 years cannot be considered to be either irrational, or unreasonable or having no nexus with the object to be achieved by reducing the age of retirement.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned Government order fixing November 30, 1967, as the date for founding the classification of teachers who should retire at the age of 55 years and those who should get the benefit of the interim orders extending the age of retirement to 58 or 60 years cannot be considered to be either irrational, or unreasonable or having no nexus with the object to be achieved by reducing the age of retirement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Article 14 reasonable classification test: intelligible differentia between teachers with prior specific extensions or High Court benefits versus others; rational nexus to policy objective of reducing retirement age to alleviate teacher unemployment.

holdings.text: The classification made by the Government does not suffer from any infirmity as it is founded on rational nexus with the object to be achieved.

anchor.surface_text: The classification made by the Government does not suffer from any infirmity as it is founded on rational nexus with the object to be achieved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification based on November 30, 1967 cutoff upheld as rationally connected to reinstating original retirement age post-cancellation of extensions, addressing unemployment without arbitrariness.

holdings.text: This clearly provides a valid differentia and the present petitioners cannot claim to be equated with those employees who had been given such benefits.

anchor.surface_text: This clearly provides a valid differentia and the present petitioners cannot claim to be equated with those employees who had been given such benefits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes petitioners from those granted High Court relief or specific extensions; valid classification under Articles 14 and 16 as different treatment based on judicially recognized rights.

holdings.text: We do not think there is any such fundamental right possessed by the present petitioners as would entitle them to claim similar relief from this Court in the present proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think there is any such fundamental right possessed by the present petitioners as would entitle them to claim similar relief from this Court in the present proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No vested right or fundamental right to continued service beyond original 55-year retirement age based on temporary government orders later cancelled; distinguishes from High Court beneficiaries.

holdings.text: it has not been shown that the teachers employed by the Municipalities, Zilla Parishads and Panchayat Samitis are governed directly by this Fundamental Rule.

anchor.surface_text: it has not been shown that the teachers employed by the Municipalities, Zilla Parishads and Panchayat Samitis are governed directly by this Fundamental Rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioners' employment under specific rules (r.14, r.16) not directly governed by FR 56(a); inconsistent with pleaded case assuming 55-year retirement; no automatic modification shown.

holdings.text: it is open to the Government in this case to reduce the age of retirement without exposing such reduction to any constitutional infirmity.

anchor.surface_text: it is open to the Government in this case to reduce the age of retirement without exposing such reduction to any constitutional infirmity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concession by petitioners accepted; government power under service rules and Art. 309 to adjust retirement age prospectively or otherwise upheld as not violating Constitution.

holdings.text: These decisions do not advance the petitioners case.

anchor.surface_text: These decisions do not advance the petitioners case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedents (Bishun Narain Mishra, Premadhar Baruah) on grounds that retention post-retirement is discretionary based on exigencies, confers no right.

holdings.text: In the final result, all the writ petitions are dismissed, but in the circumstances with no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the final result, all the writ petitions are dismissed, but in the circumstances with no order as to costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No fundamental rights violation found; all challenges to G.O. 2219, Memo 6573, G.O. 1321, and rules rejected on above grounds.

precedents.citation: B. S. Vadera v. Union of India Ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: the decision of the Supreme Court in B. S. Vadera v. Union of India Ors.  1  which upheld the validity of retrospective operation of Rules made under Art. 309 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: B. S. Vadera v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: upheld the validity of retrospective operation of Rules made under Art. 309 of the Constitution

precedents.citation: Bishun Narain Mishra v. State of Uttar Pradesh and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Singhvi referred us to Bishun Narain Mishra v. State of Uttar Pradesh and Others 1  State of Assam and others v. Premadhar Baruah and others 1  and to an unreported decision of this Court in The State of U. P. and Anr. v. Kishan Chand Dhaune .

precedents.case_name: Bishun Narain Mishra v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Government decides to retain the services of some public servants after the age of retirement it must retain every public servant for the same length of time. The retention of public servants after the period of retirement depends upon their efficiency and the exigencies of public service
precedents.cited_holding: Now it cannot be urged that if Government decides to retain the services of some public servants after the age of retirement it must retain every public servant for the same length of time. The retention of public servants after the period of retirement depends upon their efficiency and the exigencies of public service, and in the present case the difference in the period of retention has arisen on account of exigencies of public service.

precedents.citation: State of Assam and others v. Premadhar Baruah and others 1

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Singhvi referred us to Bishun Narain Mishra v. State of Uttar Pradesh and Others 1  State of Assam and others v. Premadhar Baruah and others 1  and to an unreported decision of this Court in The State of U. P. and Anr. v. Kishan Chand Dhaune .

precedents.case_name: State of Assam v. Premadhar Baruah
precedents.cited_proposition: Government could retain a Government servant beyond the age of superannuation. The Government has also the discretion to withdraw such retention in service because the retention does not confer any right on the Government servant
precedents.cited_holding: As we have already indicated paragraph 4 of the memorandum flowed from F. R. 56 a . The Government could retain a Government servant beyond the age of superannuation. The Government has also the discretion to withdraw such retention in service because the retention does not confer any right on the Government servant.

precedents.citation: The State of U. P. and Anr. v. Kishan Chand Dhaune
precedents.case_name: State of U. P. v. Kishan Chand Dhaune
